title: When the U.S. economy goes down, the dollar does too — except during a recession
text:
When the U.S. economy slows, so does the U.S. dollar — except during a recession.

That’s the finding of Goldman Sachs strategist Zach Pandl, who looked at slowdowns and recessions since the 1970s.

In a note to clients, Pandl said he examined the issue because a number of indicators, ranging from eurozone purchasing managers indexes to Korean exports — are scaring investors about the global economy.

While Goldman Sachs economists do expect the global economy to rebound, Pandl examined the outlook if things go get worse from here.

Looking at its own current activity indicator as a proxy for the U.S. economy, Pandl found 15 episodes since 1973 — 6 recessions and 9 slowdowns, including the current one.

The real trade-weighted U.S. dollar DXY, -0.07% BUXX, -0.13% tends to strengthen between the peak of growth and its trough. But what the dollar does next depends if the U.S. enters recession or not. During recessions, the dollar continues to rise, albeit mildly, he said.

Why? Pandl said it’s a flight-to-quality response even though the Fed cuts interest rates during this period.

As with any study, it does have caveats, notably that there are relatively few observations.
